title: How to Prepare for a Forest Fire

steps.headline: Replace highly flammable vegetation, such as pine and fir trees, with less flammable species.
Trim branches so there is a 15-foot (4.5 meter) gap between any treetops.
Cut your grass often so the maximum length is 2 inches (5.08 cm).
Ensure your house and deck are constructed out of fire-resistant materials.
steps.description:
It is very important that your roof is resistant, because it is the most likely to catch fire. Use materials such as fiberglass, metal, clay and concrete. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/65\/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/65\/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Clear debris such as leaves and dead wood from this area.
Reduce flammable vegetation in this area.
Store firewood and combustible materials 100 feet (30.5 meters) away from your house.
Place gas grills and propane tanks at least 15 feet (4.5 meters) away from the house.
Cover your grill with 1/4-inch (0.635 cm) mesh screen.
Avoid using grills during the dry season.
Turn off air exchange units to avoid bringing smoke into the house.
Plan several escape routes.
steps.description:
Wildfires can move quickly and cut off your escape within minutes. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/62\/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-13Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/62\/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-13Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Monitor local radio and TV channels for up-to-date information and evacuation orders.
Pack your bags and survival kits quickly.
steps.description:
Be prepared to evacuate at any time. Your survival kit should contain blankets, cash, water and nonperishable food, a first aid kit, flashlights, extra batteries, a backup radio, essential medication and whistles. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f9\/Do-Good-in-a-Championship-Meet-Step-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Do-Good-in-a-Championship-Meet-Step-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f9\/Do-Good-in-a-Championship-Meet-Step-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Do-Good-in-a-Championship-Meet-Step-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Remove combustible materials from your yard and place them outside your buffer areas.
Take down flammable drapes and other window coverings and close shutters or other noncombustible coverings to reduce heat.
steps.description:
Turn off your gas valves and pilot lights. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/87\/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-17Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/87\/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-17Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Close your doors but keep them unlocked.
steps.description:
Firefighters might need to get inside quickly to combat the fire. You should also keep a light on in every room so your house is more easily seen in the smoke. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/62\/Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-5Bullet5.jpg\/v4-460px-Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-5Bullet5.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/62\/Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-5Bullet5.jpg\/v4-760px-Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-5Bullet5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Fill any pools and large containers with water.
steps.description: Douse your roof with sprinklers or water from a few of the containers.

text:
Create the 1st Buffer Zone Replace highly flammable vegetation, such as pine and fir trees, with less flammable species. Some less flammable plant alternatives for close landscaping include Columbine, lavender, Coreopsis and Geranium. You can also plant alternative trees and shrubs further from the house. Some good options include buckthorn, lilac, maple and birch. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Keep the amount of vegetation to a bare minimum in this zone. Your 1st zone should be at least 30 feet (9.14 m) around your house. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-17Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-17Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-17Bullet4.jpg/v4-760px-Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-17Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Trim branches so there is a 15-foot (4.5 meter) gap between any treetops. Cut your grass often so the maximum length is 2 inches (5.08 cm). Ensure your house and deck are constructed out of fire-resistant materials. It is very important that your roof is resistant, because it is the most likely to catch fire. Use materials such as fiberglass, metal, clay and concrete. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Clear debris such as leaves and dead wood from this area. Create the 2nd Zone Reduce flammable vegetation in this area. You can plant alternative trees and shrubs. Some good options for this zone and beyond include buckthorn, lilac, maple and birch. Ensure all shrubs and trees are maintained and far enough away from structures. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-6Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-6Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} This area should start at the end of your 1st buffer zone and extend to at least 100 feet (30.5 meters). Your zone might extend out further if you live on a hill. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-6Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-6Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Install electrical lines underground. Store firewood and combustible materials 100 feet (30.5 meters) away from your house. Place gas grills and propane tanks at least 15 feet (4.5 meters) away from the house. Cover your grill with 1/4-inch (0.635 cm) mesh screen. Avoid using grills during the dry season. Imminent Threat of Fire Turn off air exchange units to avoid bringing smoke into the house. Plan several escape routes. Wildfires can move quickly and cut off your escape within minutes. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-13Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-13Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Monitor local radio and TV channels for up-to-date information and evacuation orders. Pack your bags and survival kits quickly. Be prepared to evacuate at any time. Your survival kit should contain blankets, cash, water and nonperishable food, a first aid kit, flashlights, extra batteries, a backup radio, essential medication and whistles. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Do-Good-in-a-Championship-Meet-Step-3.jpg/v4-460px-Do-Good-in-a-Championship-Meet-Step-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Do-Good-in-a-Championship-Meet-Step-3.jpg/v4-760px-Do-Good-in-a-Championship-Meet-Step-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Remove combustible materials from your yard and place them outside your buffer areas. Take down flammable drapes and other window coverings and close shutters or other noncombustible coverings to reduce heat. Turn off your gas valves and pilot lights. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-17Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-17Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Prepare-for-a-Forest-Fire-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Close your doors but keep them unlocked. Firefighters might need to get inside quickly to combat the fire. You should also keep a light on in every room so your house is more easily seen in the smoke. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-5Bullet5.jpg/v4-460px-Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-5Bullet5.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-5Bullet5.jpg/v4-760px-Prevent-Arson-in-Your-Community-Step-5Bullet5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Fill any pools and large containers with water. Douse your roof with sprinklers or water from a few of the containers.
